segment.source: Prepare to deploy and assess a bare metal computer
segment.target: Prepare to deploy and assess a bare metal computer

segment.source: Prepare to deploy and assess a bare metal computer
segment.target: Prepare to deploy and assess a bare metal computer

segment.source: Prepare to deploy and assess a bare metal computer
segment.target: Prepare to deploy and assess a bare metal computer

segment.source: This topic walks you through the steps that are required to prepare and add a bare metal computer to your Windows Assessment Services inventory.
segment.target: This topic walks you through the steps that are required to prepare and add a bare metal computer to your Windows Assessment Services inventory.

segment.source: You will then create a project and job that includes the computer, and also the image and answer file that are used to deploy an image to that computer before it is assessed.
segment.target: You will then create a project and job that includes the computer, and also the image and answer file that are used to deploy an image to that computer before it is assessed.

segment.source: In this topic:
segment.target: In this topic:

segment.source: Step1: Add network adapter drivers to the Boot.wim
segment.target: Step1: Add network adapter drivers to the Boot.wim

segment.source: Step 2: Prepare the Windows PE USB Drive for test computer inventory
segment.target: Step 2: Prepare the Windows PE USB Drive for test computer inventory

segment.source: Step 3: Add test computers to your inventory
segment.target: Step 3: Add test computers to your inventory

segment.source: Step 4: Add images and unattended answer files
segment.target: Step 4: Add images and unattended answer files

segment.source: Step 5: Add the assets to a project
segment.target: Step 5: Add the assets to a project

segment.source: Step 6: Add the assets to a job
segment.target: Step 6: Add the assets to a job

segment.source: Adding network adapter drivers to the Boot.wim
segment.target: Adding network adapter drivers to the Boot.wim

segment.source: Add network adapter (NIC) drivers to the Windows PE images that Windows Deployment Services uses.
segment.target: Add network adapter (NIC) drivers to the Windows PE images that Windows Deployment Services uses.

segment.source: This step is required only when the test computers require out-of-box NIC drivers so that they have network connectivity during inventory or after the Windows image is deployed.
segment.target: This step is required only when the test computers require out-of-box NIC drivers so that they have network connectivity during inventory or after the Windows image is deployed.

segment.source: You need the NIC drivers when you boot a bare metal computer (a computer that doesn’t have an operating system installed) in Windows PE.
segment.target: You need the NIC drivers when you boot a bare metal computer (a computer that doesn’t have an operating system installed) in Windows PE.

segment.source: To add NIC drivers to the boot.wim
segment.target: To add NIC drivers to the boot.wim

segment.source: On the server, create a folder for the NIC drivers and copy them to the folder.
segment.target: On the server, create a folder for the NIC drivers and copy them to the folder.

segment.source: For example, if your drivers are stored on a share, you can use a command such as the following:
segment.target: For example, if your drivers are stored on a share, you can use a command such as the following:

segment.source: Click Start, click Administrative Tools, and then click Windows Deployment Services.
segment.target: Click Start, click Administrative Tools, and then click Windows Deployment Services.

segment.source: Expand the Servers node and expand your server name.
segment.target: Expand the Servers node and expand your server name.

segment.source: Right-click Drivers, and then click Add Driver Package.
segment.target: Right-click Drivers, and then click Add Driver Package.

segment.source: In the Add Driver Package wizard, click Select all driver packages from a folder, and then click Browse.
segment.target: In the Add Driver Package wizard, click Select all driver packages from a folder, and then click Browse.

segment.source: Browse to the folder that contains the out-of-box NIC drivers, and then click OK.
segment.target: Browse to the folder that contains the out-of-box NIC drivers, and then click OK.

segment.source: In the Add Driver Package wizard, click Next.
segment.target: In the Add Driver Package wizard, click Next.

segment.source: On the Available Driver Packages page, click Next.
segment.target: On the Available Driver Packages page, click Next.

segment.source: On the Summary page, click Next.
segment.target: On the Summary page, click Next.

segment.source: When the drivers are copied to the driver store, click Next.
segment.target: When the drivers are copied to the driver store, click Next.

segment.source: On the Driver Groups page, click Select an existing driver group, verify that DriverGroup1 is selected, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Driver Groups page, click Select an existing driver group, verify that DriverGroup1 is selected, and then click Next.

segment.source: Click Finish.
segment.target: Click Finish.

segment.source: On the Servers node, click Boot Images, right-click the boot image where you want to inject the driver, and then click Add Driver Packages to Image.
segment.target: On the Servers node, click Boot Images, right-click the boot image where you want to inject the driver, and then click Add Driver Packages to Image.

segment.source: In the Add Driver Package to Boot Image Wizard, on the Before You Begin page, click Next.
segment.target: In the Add Driver Package to Boot Image Wizard, on the Before You Begin page, click Next.

segment.source: On the Select Driver Packages page, click Package Class, and then click Edit.
segment.target: On the Select Driver Packages page, click Package Class, and then click Edit.

segment.source: Delete everything except Net, and then click OK.
segment.target: Delete everything except Net, and then click OK.

segment.source: In the Add Driver Package to Boot Image Wizard, click Search for Packages, click Next, and then click Next again.
segment.target: In the Add Driver Package to Boot Image Wizard, click Search for Packages, click Next, and then click Next again.

segment.source: When the drivers are added, click Finish.
segment.target: When the drivers are added, click Finish.

segment.source: Your boot image now has out-of-box NIC drivers.
segment.target: Your boot image now has out-of-box NIC drivers.

segment.source: Repeat these steps for each Windows Deployment Services boot.wim architecture.
segment.target: Repeat these steps for each Windows Deployment Services boot.wim architecture.

segment.source: Preparing the Windows PE USB drive for test computer inventory
segment.target: Preparing the Windows PE USB drive for test computer inventory

segment.source: To inventory bare metal computers, you must create a bootable USB drive to start the computer and add it to the inventory.
segment.target: To inventory bare metal computers, you must create a bootable USB drive to start the computer and add it to the inventory.

segment.source: For more information about how to prepare a bootable Windows PE USB flash drive, see Walkthrough: Install Windows PE to CD, USB Flash Drive, or USB Hard Drive.
segment.target: For more information about how to prepare a bootable Windows PE USB flash drive, see Walkthrough: Install Windows PE to CD, USB Flash Drive, or USB Hard Drive.

segment.source: The walkthrough creates bootable media by using the default Windows PE image (WinPE.wim) without customizing it.
segment.target: The walkthrough creates bootable media by using the default Windows PE image (WinPE.wim) without customizing it.

segment.source: Before you use the bootable USB flash drive for inventory, you must copy the RelaxWinPE.wim file to the source folder on the USB flash drive, as shown in the procedure in the following section.
segment.target: Before you use the bootable USB flash drive for inventory, you must copy the RelaxWinPE.wim file to the source folder on the USB flash drive, as shown in the procedure in the following section.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: To inventory x86-based test computers, you must use an x86-based Windows PE image.
segment.target: To inventory x86-based test computers, you must use an x86-based Windows PE image.

segment.source: To inventory AMD64-based test computers, you must use an AMD64-based Windows PE image.
segment.target: To inventory AMD64-based test computers, you must use an AMD64-based Windows PE image.

segment.source: This procedure uses an x86-based image.
segment.target: This procedure uses an x86-based image.

segment.source: If your test computers are both x86 and AMD64 based, create a USB flash drive for each architecture.
segment.target: If your test computers are both x86 and AMD64 based, create a USB flash drive for each architecture.

segment.source: To replace the boot.wim file with the Windows AS WinPE.wim file
segment.target: To replace the boot.wim file with the Windows AS WinPE.wim file

segment.source: On the technician computer where you created the Windows PE build environment, type the following command:
segment.target: On the technician computer where you created the Windows PE build environment, type the following command:

segment.source: Repeat the previous step to create a USB flash drive for each architecture that you need for your test computers.
segment.target: Repeat the previous step to create a USB flash drive for each architecture that you need for your test computers.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: To inventory x86-based test computers, you must use an x86-based Windows PE image.
segment.target: To inventory x86-based test computers, you must use an x86-based Windows PE image.

segment.source: To inventory AMD64-based test computers, you must use an AMD64-based Windows PE image.
segment.target: To inventory AMD64-based test computers, you must use an AMD64-based Windows PE image.

segment.source: Now that the bootable Windows PE USB flash drive is prepared and NIC drivers are in place, you can add assets such as computers, images and answer files to the Windows Assessment Services inventory and then include the assets in your projects and jobs.
segment.target: Now that the bootable Windows PE USB flash drive is prepared and NIC drivers are in place, you can add assets such as computers, images and answer files to the Windows Assessment Services inventory and then include the assets in your projects and jobs.

segment.source: Adding test computers to your inventory
segment.target: Adding test computers to your inventory

segment.source: You can add bare-metal computers (computers without a running operating system) in addition to computers that have a running operating system to the Windows Assessment Services inventory so that you can use the assessment tools to assess these computers.
segment.target: You can add bare-metal computers (computers without a running operating system) in addition to computers that have a running operating system to the Windows Assessment Services inventory so that you can use the assessment tools to assess these computers.

segment.source: When the test computer doesn't have a running operating system, use the USB flash drive to boot and inventory the computer, as shown in procedure in the following section.
segment.target: When the test computer doesn't have a running operating system, use the USB flash drive to boot and inventory the computer, as shown in procedure in the following section.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: You shouldn't include a test computer in multiple Windows Assessment Services server inventories at the same time.
segment.target: You shouldn't include a test computer in multiple Windows Assessment Services server inventories at the same time.

segment.source: When a test computer appears in multiple Windows Assessment Services server inventories, it causes a race condition between the Windows Deployment Services instances on each server.
segment.target: When a test computer appears in multiple Windows Assessment Services server inventories, it causes a race condition between the Windows Deployment Services instances on each server.

segment.source: If you must move a test computer from one inventory to another, in the Windows Assessment Services - Client (Windows ASC), delete the computer asset from the first Windows Assessment Services inventory, and then add it to the inventory on the new Windows Assessment Services server.
segment.target: If you must move a test computer from one inventory to another, in the Windows Assessment Services - Client (Windows ASC), delete the computer asset from the first Windows Assessment Services inventory, and then add it to the inventory on the new Windows Assessment Services server.

segment.source: To add bare-metal computers to your inventory
segment.target: To add bare-metal computers to your inventory

segment.source: Insert the USB flash drive into the test computer.
segment.target: Insert the USB flash drive into the test computer.

segment.source: Turn on the computer, and press the key that opens the boot-device selection menu for the computer, such as Esc.
segment.target: Turn on the computer, and press the key that opens the boot-device selection menu for the computer, such as Esc.

segment.source: Select the USB flash drive as the boot device.
segment.target: Select the USB flash drive as the boot device.

segment.source: When the computer reboots, provide the following information:
segment.target: When the computer reboots, provide the following information:

segment.source: Computer name.
segment.target: Computer name.

segment.source: The computer name must contain only alphanumeric characters and dashes.
segment.target: The computer name must contain only alphanumeric characters and dashes.

segment.source: If the computer name contains an underscore or other extended characters, the computer may not be discoverable via Domain Name System (DNS).
segment.target: If the computer name contains an underscore or other extended characters, the computer may not be discoverable via Domain Name System (DNS).

segment.source: The computer name must be 15 characters or less.
segment.target: The computer name must be 15 characters or less.

segment.source: Computer location.
segment.target: Computer location.

segment.source: The computer location must be 78 characters or less.
segment.target: The computer location must be 78 characters or less.

segment.source: Whether you want to perform Driver Scavenge.
segment.target: Whether you want to perform Driver Scavenge.

segment.source: Driver Scavenge copies drivers found on the computer to the Windows Assessment Services driver store.
segment.target: Driver Scavenge copies drivers found on the computer to the Windows Assessment Services driver store.

segment.source: Remove the USB flash drive from the test computer.
segment.target: Remove the USB flash drive from the test computer.

segment.source: The computer will reboot.
segment.target: The computer will reboot.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you deploy images by using Windows Assessment Services, we recommend setting the boot order in BIOS so that Preboot Execution Environment (PXE) is first in the boot order.
segment.target: If you deploy images by using Windows Assessment Services, we recommend setting the boot order in BIOS so that Preboot Execution Environment (PXE) is first in the boot order.

segment.source: This way, you don't have to manually press the boot-order keyboard shortcut and select network boot before a job starts.
segment.target: This way, you don't have to manually press the boot-order keyboard shortcut and select network boot before a job starts.

segment.source: Open the Windows ASC from the Start menu.
segment.target: Open the Windows ASC from the Start menu.

segment.source: On the Getting Started page, verify that the correct number of computers have been added to your server inventory.
segment.target: On the Getting Started page, verify that the correct number of computers have been added to your server inventory.

segment.source: Adding images and unattended answer Files
segment.target: Adding images and unattended answer Files

segment.source: You must copy the Windows imaging (.wim) files to the image share before you import them to the Windows Assessment Services inventory and use them for deployment.
segment.target: You must copy the Windows imaging (.wim) files to the image share before you import them to the Windows Assessment Services inventory and use them for deployment.

segment.source: The answer files that you want to use for deployment must also be available in the appropriate server share.
segment.target: The answer files that you want to use for deployment must also be available in the appropriate server share.

segment.source: To add images to the image share and inventory
segment.target: To add images to the image share and inventory

segment.source: On the Windows Assessment Services server, copy your .wim files to C:relaximages.
segment.target: On the Windows Assessment Services server, copy your .wim files to C:relaximages.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The image path cannot contain spaces.
segment.target: The image path cannot contain spaces.

segment.source: These images are in the Windows Assessment Services server image share, but they haven't been imported into the inventory database.
segment.target: These images are in the Windows Assessment Services server image share, but they haven't been imported into the inventory database.

segment.source: To import the images into the inventory database, use one of these methods:
segment.target: To import the images into the inventory database, use one of these methods:

segment.source: On the Getting Started page, click Import images now, select the images, click Import, and then click OK.
segment.target: On the Getting Started page, click Import images now, select the images, click Import, and then click OK.

segment.source: In the Windows ASC, on the Server menu, click Manager inventory, click the Images tab, and then click Add.
segment.target: In the Windows ASC, on the Server menu, click Manager inventory, click the Images tab, and then click Add.

segment.source: To add answer files to a share
segment.target: To add answer files to a share

segment.source: A default Unattend.xml answer file for each supported architecture is provided at %systemdrive%relaxscriptstemplates.
segment.target: A default Unattend.xml answer file for each supported architecture is provided at %systemdrive%relaxscriptstemplates.

segment.source: You can use the default answer file, or you can copy the template Unattend.xml and modify it in Windows System Image Manager.
segment.target: You can use the default answer file, or you can copy the template Unattend.xml and modify it in Windows System Image Manager.

segment.source: For more information about how to modify an answer file, see the Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM) Technical Reference.
segment.target: For more information about how to modify an answer file, see the Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM) Technical Reference.

segment.source: Copy Unattend.xml answer files to %systemdrive%relaxunattendfiles.
segment.target: Copy Unattend.xml answer files to %systemdrive%relaxunattendfiles.

segment.source: If you provide separate unattended answer files for specific images, give each new answer file a unique name before you copy it to %systemdrive%relaxunattendfiles.
segment.target: If you provide separate unattended answer files for specific images, give each new answer file a unique name before you copy it to %systemdrive%relaxunattendfiles.

segment.source: When you add images to a project in the Windows ASC, specify the path of the answer file that you want to use with that image.
segment.target: When you add images to a project in the Windows ASC, specify the path of the answer file that you want to use with that image.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: When deploying an image to an OEM Activation 3.0 (OA 3.0) system, use a custom unattend.xml answer file with a product key that is associated with the image.
segment.target: When deploying an image to an OEM Activation 3.0 (OA 3.0) system, use a custom unattend.xml answer file with a product key that is associated with the image.

segment.source: Adding assets to a project
segment.target: Adding assets to a project

segment.source: A project is a collection of assets that you want to assess.
segment.target: A project is a collection of assets that you want to assess.

segment.source: It identifies multiple computers and multiple images that are a subset of all the computers and images that you added to your inventory.
segment.target: It identifies multiple computers and multiple images that are a subset of all the computers and images that you added to your inventory.

segment.source: If the computers that you add to the project are bare metal computers, or if you want to refresh the image on the test computer, you also select the images that you want to apply to each computer.
segment.target: If the computers that you add to the project are bare metal computers, or if you want to refresh the image on the test computer, you also select the images that you want to apply to each computer.

segment.source: When multiple people are working with different test computers and images in the same server inventory, you can use projects to partition an individual's workspace.
segment.target: When multiple people are working with different test computers and images in the same server inventory, you can use projects to partition an individual's workspace.

segment.source: To add assets to a new project
segment.target: To add assets to a new project

segment.source: In the Windows ASC, on the Getting Started page, click Create New Project.
segment.target: In the Windows ASC, on the Getting Started page, click Create New Project.

segment.source: In the Project name box, type a name for your project.
segment.target: In the Project name box, type a name for your project.

segment.source: In the Description box, type a description.
segment.target: In the Description box, type a description.

segment.source: In the Keywords box, enter keywords, and then click Next.
segment.target: In the Keywords box, enter keywords, and then click Next.

segment.source: In the Select machines to include in this project window, click Add and select the computer that you want to include in this project, click OK, and then click Next.
segment.target: In the Select machines to include in this project window, click Add and select the computer that you want to include in this project, click OK, and then click Next.

segment.source: In the Image Inventory window, click Add and select images to add to your project, click OK, and then click Finish.
segment.target: In the Image Inventory window, click Add and select images to add to your project, click OK, and then click Finish.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If your test computers already have a running operating system, you don't have to add images to the project.
segment.target: If your test computers already have a running operating system, you don't have to add images to the project.

segment.source: Adding assets to a job
segment.target: Adding assets to a job

segment.source: A job associates assets (a computer and a Windows image) with assessments.
segment.target: A job associates assets (a computer and a Windows image) with assessments.

segment.source: A job can contain multiple computers, the corresponding images and unattended answer files, and multiple assessments.
segment.target: A job can contain multiple computers, the corresponding images and unattended answer files, and multiple assessments.

segment.source: You can use all the assets that were added to the project, use only a subset of those assets, or run different jobs on different assets that are available in the project.
segment.target: You can use all the assets that were added to the project, use only a subset of those assets, or run different jobs on different assets that are available in the project.

segment.source: To add assets to a job and deploy an image
segment.target: To add assets to a job and deploy an image

segment.source: In the Windows ASC, create or open a job.
segment.target: In the Windows ASC, create or open a job.

segment.source: Under Job settings, click Overview, and verify that the Apply image check box is selected.
segment.target: Under Job settings, click Overview, and verify that the Apply image check box is selected.

segment.source: If you want to inject matching Plug and Play drivers from a Dynamic Driver Provisioning driver store during image deployment, select Dynamic Driver Provisioning.
segment.target: If you want to inject matching Plug and Play drivers from a Dynamic Driver Provisioning driver store during image deployment, select Dynamic Driver Provisioning.

segment.source: Under Job settings, click Assets, and then click Add to select the computers that you want run the job on.
segment.target: Under Job settings, click Assets, and then click Add to select the computers that you want run the job on.

segment.source: In the Select Evaluation Assets window, select the computers that you want to assess, click Next, and then click Finish.
segment.target: In the Select Evaluation Assets window, select the computers that you want to assess, click Next, and then click Finish.

segment.source: The computers appear on the right side of the Windows ASC under Evaluation assets.
segment.target: The computers appear on the right side of the Windows ASC under Evaluation assets.

segment.source: Select a computer, click Change Image, select the image that you want to apply to that computer, and then click OK.
segment.target: Select a computer, click Change Image, select the image that you want to apply to that computer, and then click OK.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The computer and the image architecture must match, except that you can select an x86-based image to deploy to an x64-based computer.
segment.target: The computer and the image architecture must match, except that you can select an x86-based image to deploy to an x64-based computer.

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: In these steps, you prepared the Windows PE boot environment, booted a bare metal computer and added it to the Windows Assessment Services inventory.
segment.target: In these steps, you prepared the Windows PE boot environment, booted a bare metal computer and added it to the Windows Assessment Services inventory.

segment.source: Then you added the computers, images, and answer files to the server inventory and created a project and a job that included these assets.
segment.target: Then you added the computers, images, and answer files to the server inventory and created a project and a job that included these assets.

segment.source: The next step is to add assessments to the job, configure the job and assessment settings, and then click Run.
segment.target: The next step is to add assessments to the job, configure the job and assessment settings, and then click Run.

segment.source: When you run the job, the Windows image is deployed to the computer before the assessments that are included in the job are run.
segment.target: When you run the job, the Windows image is deployed to the computer before the assessments that are included in the job are run.

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics

segment.source: Windows Assessment Services common scenarios
segment.target: Windows Assessment Services common scenarios
